image.altText: A Woolworths sign next to a Coles sign outside the shops

items.synopsis: Analysis by investment bank UBS finds food prices at Australia's major supermarket chains have risen at a faster rate than inflation.

title.children: Supermarket food prices outpace inflation, rising by 'surprising' 10pc in past year

image.altText: Tim Pallas appears serious as he stands outside, speaking in a suit.

items.synopsis: Big businesses, holiday-home owners and landlords will be asked to foot the bill for the Victorian government's COVID-19 debt, as part of a 10-year budget repair plan unveiled in the state budget.

title.children: Victorian budget targets big employers and property investors with 'COVID Debt Levy'

image.altText: A graphic showing BoM and NOAA odds of El Nino

items.synopsis: The BOM's latest climate update keeps the possibility of El Niño at 50 per cent, but the US's chief forecast agency, NOAA, says it's a 90 per cent chance.

title.children: US and Australia project vastly different odds of El Niño developing. Who is right?

image.altText: Mike gestures, standing in parliament wearing a suit and tie.

items.synopsis: Yesterday, Stephen Mitchell was sentenced to more than 13 years in jail for a raft of child sex offences, which police had been investigating prior to his employment with the Department of Home Affairs.

title.children: Home Affairs officials grilled over employment of man under investigation for child sex offences

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: Clare Nowland fell and fractured her skull last week after she was tasered by the senior constable who had been called to her aged-care home in Cooma, because she was carrying a knife.

title.children: Senior constable suspended after tasering 95yo NSW great-grandmother

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: The Transport Workers Union is calling on Qantas to repay $2.7 billion in government handouts it got during the COVID-19 pandemic as the airline forecasts what the union calls an 'obscene' record annual profit. And the Australian share market gains on hopes of a US debt ceiling deal.

title.children: Transport union demands Qantas pay back $2.7 billion pandemic relief as airline sees record annual profit, ASX higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Staying on the airlines, some members of Virgin Australia's Velocity Frequent Flyer program need to start using their accounts again before the end of June, otherwise their balances will expire. That's for customer accounts that have been inactive for three years. Virgin Australia says it extended the value of points balances in July 2022 to at least 30 June 2023, because of the difficulty faced by travelers during COVID-19. A Virgin Australia spokesperson says customers need to earn or redeem points before the end of June to reactivate their accounts. "Those impacted by the coming expiry will have had no activity on their accounts for three years." "Members can extend the validity of their balances by earning or redeeming as little as a single point, which will automatically renew their balances for another two years." Meanwhile, Bloomberg is reporting that Virgin Australia's owner Bain Capital wants to relist the airline on the stock exchange in November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Virgin says some Velocity points are expiring

children.content: Staying on the airlines, some members of Virgin Australia's Velocity Frequent Flyer program need to start using their accounts again before the end of June, otherwise their balances will expire.
That's for customer accounts that have been inactive for three years.
Virgin Australia says it extended the value of points balances in July 2022 to at least 30 June 2023, because of the difficulty faced by travelers during COVID-19.
A Virgin Australia spokesperson says customers need to earn or redeem points before the end of June to reactivate their accounts.
"Those impacted by the coming expiry will have had no activity on their accounts for three years."
"Members can extend the validity of their balances by earning or redeeming as little as a single point, which will automatically renew their balances for another two years."
Meanwhile, Bloomberg is reporting that Virgin Australia's owner Bain Capital wants to relist the airline on the stock exchange in November.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Transport Workers Union has called on Qantas to pay back the $2.7 billion worth of government support it received during the COVID-19 pandemic. That's after Qantas forecast a record before tax profit of nearly $2.5 billion for this financial year thanks to a rebound in demand for travel. The TWU has also slammed a $100 million increase in the airline's share buyback scheme for investors. Here is TWU national secretary Michael Kaine: "This obscene profit forecast is the result of Qantas management bleeding dry workers, passengers and the tax paying public." "The right thing to do would be to pay back every dollar of no-strings government handouts Qantas received from Scott Morrison before it trashed every essential section of the airline to prop up executives and shareholders." "The $100 million increase to the share buyback scheme is a kick in the guts to illegally sacked workers who were told their jobs were sacrificed to save this amount of money," Mr Kaine said. For more on the High Court battle between Qantas and TWU over the outsourcing of baggage handler jobs, here is my colleague, Elizabeth Byrne.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TWU says Qantas should pay back pandemic support

featuredLink.title: High Court to hear battle between Qantas and Transport Workers' Union over ground crew outsourcing

children.content: The Transport Workers Union has called on Qantas to pay back the $2.7 billion worth of government support it received during the COVID-19 pandemic.
That's after Qantas forecast a record before tax profit of nearly $2.5 billion for this financial year thanks to a rebound in demand for travel.
The TWU has also slammed a $100 million increase in the airline's share buyback scheme for investors.
Here is TWU national secretary Michael Kaine:
"This obscene profit forecast is the result of Qantas management bleeding dry workers, passengers and the tax paying public."

"The right thing to do would be to pay back every dollar of no-strings government handouts Qantas received from Scott Morrison before it trashed every essential section of the airline to prop up executives and shareholders."
"The $100 million increase to the share buyback scheme is a kick in the guts to illegally sacked workers who were told their jobs were sacrificed to save this amount of money," Mr Kaine said.
For more on the High Court battle between Qantas and TWU over the outsourcing of baggage handler jobs, here is my colleague, Elizabeth Byrne.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: National Australia Bank has increased mortgage rates on variable rate home loans for new customers for the third time in three months. That is for owner occupiers and investors with a deposit greater than 20 per cent. The 0.1 percentage point rise is on top of official rate rises by the Reserve Bank. That means NAB's lowest variable rate home loan has increased by 0.75 per cent since March 1 for new customers, while existing customers have seen their rates increase by 0.5 percentage points. Canstar says it is the second variable home loan rate increase from NAB in less than a fortnight. It's also the fourth time the lender has increased variable rates out of cycle with the RBA's cash rate decisions according to Canstar. Canstar’s finance expert, Steve Mickenbecker says it is bad news for borrowers as smaller lenders are also likely to follow suit. “﻿NAB’s second variable home loan rate increase in a fortnight will further disturb borrowers already shell-shocked after a year of rate hikes.” “The Reserve Bank cash rate rise in May had already added $79 to the monthly repayment on a $500,000 basic variable loan at NAB, and the 0.10 per cent rise tops this up to $112. “Bank margins are coming under pressure as depositors are finally starting to receive the full benefit of Reserve Bank cash rate increases, and other funding costs have already risen to more normal levels after the years of COVID support." “Out of cycle increases by the big banks will ease the pressure on smaller lenders that are without large deposit bases, potentially allowing them to reprice their home loans to cover their higher cost of funding." RateCity says all the big four banks have increased new customer rates in the last three months, in addition to the RBA rate hikes in March and May.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB raises mortgage rates for third time in three months

children.content: National Australia Bank has increased mortgage rates on variable rate home loans for new customers for the third time in three months.
That is for owner occupiers and investors with a deposit greater than 20 per cent.
The 0.1 percentage point rise is on top of official rate rises by the Reserve Bank.

props.alt: NAB increases standard variable interest rates for new customers

children.content: NAB rates rise
(Canstar)
That means NAB's lowest variable rate home loan has increased by 0.75 per cent since March 1 for new customers, while existing customers have seen their rates increase by 0.5 percentage points.
Canstar says it is the second variable home loan rate increase from NAB in less than a fortnight.
It's also the fourth time the lender has increased variable rates out of cycle with the RBA's cash rate decisions according to Canstar.
Canstar’s finance expert, Steve Mickenbecker says it is bad news for borrowers as smaller lenders are also likely to follow suit.
“﻿NAB’s second variable home loan rate increase in a fortnight will further disturb borrowers already shell-shocked after a year of rate hikes.”
“The Reserve Bank cash rate rise in May had already added $79 to the monthly repayment on a $500,000 basic variable loan at NAB, and the 0.10 per cent rise tops this up to $112.

“Bank margins are coming under pressure as depositors are finally starting to receive the full benefit of Reserve Bank cash rate increases, and other funding costs have already risen to more normal levels after the years of COVID support."

“Out of cycle increases by the big banks will ease the pressure on smaller lenders that are without large deposit bases, potentially allowing them to reprice their home loans to cover their higher cost of funding."
RateCity says all the big four banks have increased new customer rates in the last three months, in addition to the RBA rate hikes in March and May.

props.alt: Table of home loan rate rises by big banks

children.content: Big bank rate rises
(RateCity)

image.altText: A collation of images showing Damien Hardwick celebrate milestones in his career.

items.synopsis: Damien Hardwick's legacy is one of ultimate success and tactical genius, but if not for support from above, he may never have had a chance to create it, writes Kyle Pollard.

title.children: Damien Hardwick leaves Richmond as one of the coaching greats — but it was so close to being a different story

image.altText: A person wearing personal protective equipment holding up a SARS COVID-19 rapid antigen test swab

items.synopsis: As the temperature drops, Australia is approaching its fifth COVID wave. This is what it could look like.

title.children: Australia is approaching its fifth COVID-19 wave. What can we expect this time?

image.altText: People holding umbrellas gather outside an orange terrace house with a for lease sign out the front.

items.synopsis: Property managers are often the only contact point renters have for their landlords, and agents must act in the best interests of their client. As the rental crisis continues, we take a look at who's pulling the strings.

title.children: 'I've got some very greedy landlords at the moment': Behind the scenes of Australia's rental crisis

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: A Treasury investigation into the impact of a PwC tax expert's use of confidential information — sold to clients seeking to minimise tax — could lead to the firm being referred to the Australian Federal Police, the assistant treasurer warns.

title.children: PwC breached the Australian government's trust, now it is facing the consequences

image.altText: Nigel Ng on stage with a microphone in his hand.

items.synopsis: The Chinese social media account of a Malaysian comedian best known for mocking Western chefs is banned after making jokes about China.

title.children: Comedian Uncle Roger silenced on Chinese social media after jokes about China

image.altText: Two men and a woman sit in an ornate meeting room with paintings of former US presidents on the wall.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy end their discussions with no agreement on how to raise the United States government's $47.14 trillion debt ceiling, but they will keep talking.

title.children: US debt ceiling talks end in stalemate but House Speaker McCarthy vows to talk to President Biden until deal is done

image.altText: A man dressed in snow gear, in the snow, raises a fist in triumph

image.altText: Wind turbines behind solar panels on a sunny day

items.synopsis: The department in charge of the Climate Change Authority (CCA) has told senate estimates it's seeking legal advice over potential conflicts of interest on the authority's board.

image.altText: A photo from above of the Great Barrier Reef shades of blue ocean

items.synopsis: Researchers have discovered some coral in the Great Barrier Reef — one of the seven wonders of the natural world — is infested with a close relative of the chlamydia-causing bacteria. So, is this bacteria detrimental or beneficial to corals?

title.children: Chlamydia-like bacteria found in Great Barrier Reef, study finds

image.altText: US Air Force F-16 fighter jets in the sky.

items.synopsis: The destructive power and global availability of F-16 jets is expected to help break the land warfare slog and shift the balance Ukraine's way, but it's unlikely that will happen anytime soon.

title.children: Here come the jets. Can Western air power shift Ukraine's battlefield balance?

image.altText: Two women stand in front of black-and-white photos of rock climbing.

items.synopsis: A court has heard Stephen Mitchell created a web of lies and fabrications in order to sexually assault six little girls who trusted him — this week, the former rock climbing instructor was finally punished.

title.children: After almost 30 years, these women are finally seeing justice for the abuse they suffered as children

image.altText: police scene

items.synopsis: A man who fired bullets into traffic and took two men hostage in a Wollongong street "probably did not know his act was wrong" such was the state of his mental health, a court has heard.

title.children: Gunman found not guilty of alleged terrorism due to schizophrenia

image.altText: Cars line up near roundabout

title.children: Noosa's luxury dining, shopping strip 'trying to get ahead' of potential hepatitis A outbreak

image.altText: A map of Victoria with red, blue and green tabs saying winner, loser, neutral.

items.synopsis: See how the Victorian government prioritised spending in its post-election budget.

title.children: Victorian budget 2023: Winners and losers

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Perth

items.synopsis: A year after it was elected, there's a lot to celebrate for the Albanese government in delivering its agenda. But some election promises it made are in trouble, writes RMIT ABC Fact Check's Matt Martino.

title.children: Promises can sink prime ministers. A year after the election, here are the ones to watch

image.altText: A black-and-white photo of a young boy.

items.synopsis: Buckingham Palace denies a request to return the remains of a teenage Ethiopian prince who was buried at Windsor Castle, saying that disinterring him would disturb the remains of others.

image.altText: A nurse with a tattooed arm injects a bearded man in a hospital clinic

items.synopsis: Researchers at Brisbane's Mater Hospital are starting to trial a vaccine that could mean flu jabs are only necessary every few years, instead of annually.

image.altText: Halle and Alison

items.synopsis: Draft international guidelines on polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) highlight how weight stigma — being judged or discriminated against because of our weight — can prevent women from getting the proper treatment and support they deserve.

image.altText: A waterway flowing through dark brown mud flats.

items.synopsis: The 20-year-old was walking on tidal mudflats with friends in an Alaska estuary when he got stuck in the quicksand-like silt and drowned.

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy disembarks French government plane.

image.altText: A man stares at the camera while wearing a rugby league jersey
